inference:
Since $PQ=PR$, $\triangle PQR$ is isosceles.  Thus, $\angle PQR = \angle PRQ = x$.
By the angle bisector theorem, $\angle SQP = \angle PQR = x$.
In $\triangle PQR$, the sum of angles is $180^\circ$.
$x + x + \angle QPR = 180^\circ$
$2x + \angle QPR = 180^\circ$
In $\triangle PQS$, $\angle RPQ = 3y^\circ$.  $\angle RSQ = 2y^\circ$.
In $\triangle PQR$, $\angle PQR = x$ and $\angle QPR = 180^\circ - 2x$.
Given that $QP$ bisects $\angle SQR$, we have $\angle SQP = x$.
$\angle PQR = x$.
Also, $\angle PRQ = x$, and $\angle RPQ = 3y$.
In $\triangle RPQ$, we have $\angle RPQ + \angle PRQ + \angle PQR = 180^\circ$.
$3y + x + x = 180^\circ$
$3y + 2x = 180^\circ$.
In $\triangle QRS$, $\angle SQR = 2x$.
In $\triangle QRS$, $\angle QRS = 180^\circ - (2y + 2x) = 180 - 2x - 2y$.
By the angle bisector theorem, $\angle PQR = x$. Thus, $\angle SQP = x$.
In $\triangle PQR$, we have $x + x + 3y = 180^\circ$, which simplifies to $2x + 3y = 180^\circ$.
In $\triangle QRS$, we have $x + 2y + (180^\circ - 2x) = 180^\circ$, which gives $2y + 180^\circ - x = 180^\circ$, so $2y = x$.
Substituting $2y = x$ into $2x + 3y = 180^\circ$, we get $2(2y) + 3y = 180^\circ$.
$4y + 3y = 180^\circ$
$7y = 180^\circ$
$y = \frac{180}{7}^\circ$
$\angle RPQ = 3y = 3 \left( \frac{180}{7} \right) = \frac{540}{7} \approx 77.14^\circ$.
$\angle RPQ = 3y = 3 \times \frac{180}{7} = \frac{540}{7} \approx 77.14$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{77}$
